keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008, and sentenced to a prison term ranging from five years to life under Utah law.
Rossi faked his death in 2020 by publishing an online obituary claiming he had died of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which allowed him to flee the U.S. and evade arrest.
He was identified through a DNA rape kit backlog in 2018 and later arrested in Scotland in 2024 after being recognized by hospital staff via distinctive tattoos, including one of Brown University.
Rossi used multiple aliases over the years, including Arthur Knight, to evade capture and had a history of sex offenses, including a prior conviction in Ohio.
The victim in the first case testified about being groomed and financially exploited, and the case emphasized the trauma and lasting impact of sexual violence.
Utah law allows prison sentences to be given as a range, and Rossi’s sentence is the full range of possible time (five years to life) for a first-degree felony rape.
Rossi did not testify during trial and maintained his innocence during sentencing, asserting that the women were lying.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Utah man named Nicholas Rossi, whose real name is Nicholas Alahverdian, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008. After being identified via a DNA rape kit backlog in 2018, Rossi faked his death in 2020 by publishing an online obituary, enabling him to flee the U.S. and evade justice. He was later arrested in Scotland in 2024, recognized by distinctive tattoos including one of Brown University, and extradited to Utah. A judge sentenced him to a prison term ranging from five years to life, citing him as a 'serial abuser' and 'flight risk.' The case highlights the dangers of sexual violence, the role of DNA backlogs in solving cold cases, and the lengths perpetrators will go to evade justice through deception and false identities.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
